channel.title: Humour on Simba Tango
channel.description: Recent content in Humour on Simba Tango

item.title: Masochism Tango | Tom Lehrer
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: This is a long term favorite, no wonder people have the freakiest ideas about us tango dancers… It should clear up once and for all, that dancing tango is not any fun. I never knew much about Tom Lehrer, though. I recommend this excellent BuzzFeed piece on Tom Lehrer, in addition to checking out his other oevre of course. It has generally aged pretty well.

item.title: Find One Error
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: This is a great idea! Trouvez l’erreur! from Les Pas Parfaits de Montréal. Simple, funny and well executed. Drawings by Véronique Paquette. My French is a bit rusty, but I believe the drawings are free to use for non-commercial purposes, and that it is allowed to translate them and incorporate translations in the images. Makes me want to go to Montréal!

item.title: Vero Tango Quotes
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: During a class. "Good. Now that you know the move, try to enjoy it." "What?" "Enjoy it!" "Oh shit." Enjoy.

item.title: Nostalgia
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: I some times muse over the multiple levels of nostalgia in tango. Today we are (at least to some degree) nostalgic about the golden age of tango, peaking in the 1940s. Tango, of course, was already nostalgic about the turn of the century during the golden age. Now, I always thought of this as layered or maybe even recursive nostalgia, beging nostalgic about the nostalgia of the 1940s. Add the nostalgia being a long way from Buenos Aires and longing back to being nostalgic about how they were nostalgic about the fin de ciecle in the golden age, and you get the picture… Even the nostalgia was better in the old days.

item.title: Baldosa
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: I think they make the point very clear.

item.title: ¡Felíz día del tango!
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: Even Google in Argentina celebrates the day of tango! HT: El Tangauta

item.title: The Tango Cynic -- So You Want to Learn Tango?
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: I want to be consumed by the passion and the drama, LOL! This is so funny. Complete with appropriately utterly and completely messed up American computerized pronounciaction of everything Spanish. HT: Laura

item.title: Nightmare
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)

item.title: Tango & Football
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: I’m a little late to post about tango and football, they have been playing for a week already in the World Cup. I deejayed on the opening night and made sure to play a couple of football-related songs, Independiente Club and Racing Club. Don’t think anyone noticed though. Since I’m not really into football, I sort of cheer for Argentina, and they are doing well so far.

item.title: A Better Slogan
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: by law_keven Time to upgrade my deejaying slogan. While I still sort of like the tongue in cheek fluffy deejay advertisment in-joke of **Keine komische Musik, **it has several problems. It is in German, and doesn’t really translate well. I’m not sure people get the joke, they may not even understand German. Also it may come off a bit negative. I would prefer a more positive note, so to speak.

item.title: Funny Animation by Artur Marcol
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: A friend just sent me this Polish piece, called Tango Argentino, and I thought you might enjoy it as well. Did anyone say dancing for the woman…?

item.title: Tango™
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: by ehfisher ## (...)[L]ife's most vital meeting (...) (...)[I]nspired by the meeting of male and female: man and woman. The feminine in the masculine subconscious (Anima) and the masculine in the female subconscious (Animus), and the complementary in the two archetypal sides. Tango (...) exudes passion, pride, love and attraction (...) Take pleasure in the dance (...) Not about a class or show, but about salt and pepper mills.

item.title: Not so easy
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: by Simba tango A teacher and his former student, on his first trip to Buenos Aires, run into each other outside La Glorieta and starts to chat. Suddenly the student bursts out: **A:** (about the music) This is milonga, right? **S: **No, this is tango. The conversation is drawing to an end, as the teacher is heading home. They talk for another minute, until the next song of the tanda starts and the student is eager to dance more:

item.title: Hola Papa Noel...
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: Did you check your list twice? This is old, but I saved it for Christmas time. Not really related to tango, except we were introduced to it by tango people. In spring. My wife’s pregnancy was just becoming official, and the unborn baby instantly earned his first nickname: Jorgito. –But don’t name him Jorgito, that’s not nice.

item.title: Your most underrated skill set
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)

item.title: Thrill your partners... (1940)
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: **Jim used to wonder** why he never enjoyed dancing---why he hesitated whenever he asked a friend to be his partner. One evening when he was trying to make up his mind to ask a very charming young lady to dance, he suddenly realized that if his dancing were more modern... he would get more enjoyment out of life. Jim took a few lessons at the Arthur Murray Studios. Today he is not only an excellent dancer, but he has also gained poise and confidence.

item.title: Obsessive?
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: I’m not in the market for a new car, but somehow the heading of this ad struck a nerve…

item.title: Tango in music videos
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: Old but good: tango (the dance) is used to sell musical forms that may have little in common with tango. These examples show that cliches can be treated elegantly and with humour. Not to say that the dancing is necessarily very elegant… My favorite: the Van Damage. The gotan one is quite cool, too.

item.title: Tango @ Times Square
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: Above: Simba @ Times Square Below: Los Hermanos Macana @ Times Square

item.title: El Celulareo
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: [caption id=“attachment_577” align=“alignnone” width=“539” caption=“El Celulareo?”][/caption] Based on the recent discussion on mobile phones in the milongas. This is the cartoon I mentioned, from B.A. Tango No 198. "It is astounding Brown. The mobile phone has invaded even the milongas." "Shall we dance, Rosita?" "Yes, José!" "I'll finish my coffee and we'll dance." "I'll be waiting for you, Adriana" PS: You can subscribe to B.A. Tango by email by sending an email to abatango@yahoo.

item.title: Tango Uruguayo
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: Apropos good neighbours, the Argentines are apparently constantly quarreling with the Uruguayans about things tango related. Given that La cumparsita was composed by an Uruguayan and the birth place of Gardel is still a matter of discussion. So here is an example of the excellent tango uruguayo, presented by the eminent Walter and Waldo. Hilarious.

item.title: Why the Chileans love tango
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: by f _ d a y --Do you know why the Chileans love tango? I have made a couple of Chilean friends lately, and that means opportunities to practice my castellano. In all countries, the residents make jokes about their neighbours, and one of my new friends told me this one. Another invited us to his asado (or bbq as they say here), and kept insisting on me saying** **tu, not vos like in Argentina.

item.title: Stuff without the stuff
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: by?Simba tango There was a discussion on the tango dj mailing list a while ago about people wanting “stuff without the stuff”. In other words, tango (dance) without tango (music). An oxymoron, one would think. Stephen Brown put it so well with his little story: A number of years ago, I was in a coffee shop that offered coffee prepared many different ways. One of the ways was decaffeinated coffee with artificial sweetener and artificial cream.

item.title: 3 x Squeezebox
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: by Simba tango Maybe it it time to go back to Debian. Then I could listen to Aníbal playing the squeezebox (by Arnold), streamed to my squeezebox (by Slim Devices/Logitech) from my squeezebox (running Debian).

item.title: White powder vs. Tango Argentino
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: Powder Mountain Perspective from Ian Provo on Vimeo. Common (could be pro or con, depending…): Balance Rhythm Dissociation Improvisation Flow Max 12 min. rush Addictive Skiing pros Fresh air Beautiful mountains Keeps you in shape Skiing cons Avalanches Weather dependent Cold, dress accordingly Tough ascents Heavy on the knees Practical clothing

item.title: No-one will talk to you at parties
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: by Thomas Hawk Being serious about tango doesn’t mean you have to take yourself too seriously.

item.title: Humbleness
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: by herval I just heard this story, and found it hilarious, about a dancer complaining to the dj. The conversation went something like this: -Ur music sux, man! -Allriiiight... which song would you like me to play? -! -Just name one song you would like me to play... -!! -Sooo... you don't actually know any songs, do you... Needless to say; before complaing, you ought to know what you are talking about.

item.title: Keine komische Musik
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: by emurray I was warned once in a milonga in Central Europe: We have to dance **now, **this is milonga, he won’t play much of it. Later there will only be _komische Musik _(comical music). This is the best excuse I have ever heard for asking someone (me) to dance! And she was right. The dj had no clue whatsoever and played a lot of – well, komische Musik.

item.title: It can be fun, too!
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: Just because tango can be deep and serious, doesn’t mean it can’t be a lot of fun, too. I remember learning very early about the three musical genres: milonga was fun, tango serious and vals about love… …so no coincidence that two out of three are milongas: httpv://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=98CmUhcJWbwhttpv://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=98CmUhcJWbw httpvh://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=97B2vGyZ6j0 httpvh://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=S-mkR-KoPts

item.title: The tyranny of novelty
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: by Jacob Bøtter The man who has journeyed all over the world can't find any novelty in five thousand miles, for he finds only new things -- yet another novelty, the old routine of the forever new -- while his abstract concept of novelty got lost at sea after the second new thing he saw. _The Book of Disquiet (171) by Fernando Pessoa_ As in fashion, people in dance seem always to be chasing the new black.

item.title: Almost there
item.author: simbatango@gmail.com (Simba)
item.description: by patsun They say it takes 10 years learning to walk… Almost there ;-)
